answer: In this memoir of Narciso Rodriguez's life, the mood containing it all was grateful and showed how his parents gave him love throughout his whole life. Both his parents were born and raised in Cuba, and in 1956, they both moved to the United States, starting their lives over and taking any job they could find. Then in 1961, Narciso Rodriguez was born. Both parents raised him with love, care, and introduced his Cuban background into his life.  As Narciso was telling his story, all readers could tell how grateful he was to have a family like he did. He also shared his non-blood related family and the remembrance of how his parents' lives changed by moving to the United States, showing the respect he had towards them. The love and support he received from his family shaped him into the person he is today, and he will always be grateful for their influence on his life.

Throughout the excerpt from Home the Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez, the author, manages to maintain a single overall mood. In many parts of the story he tells about how much he loved his childhood so it lead me to think was nostalgia, but nowhere does it emphasize that he yearns to return to past times. He always declared how loving and selfless his family was, how they aided others, and how he became" family" with his neighbors. Due to this I have found the tone to be, loving and admiring towards his parents. This is so due to the fact that he states how his parents were so brave to leave their lives in Cuba behind just so he could have a better life. Narciso Rodriguez also remarks numerous times on how his parents helped so many in need. If in Rodriguez's position I would love and admire my parents just as much, if not more, for their selfless deeds and upbringing of their son.

The mood the author created in the memoir is love. the author finds out that family doesn't have to be blood related. In the author's neighborhood "despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in solidarity and friendship" (@NUM1). The author loves their parents because they came "as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life" (@NUM2). The author is very grateful that her parents "Mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" (@NUM3). The author's parents gave him a great life by moving to @LOCATION1 and "turned this simple house into a @NUM4. The author's parents' sacrifices and hard work are deeply appreciated, and their love and dedication have created a strong bond within the family, proving that love knows no boundaries.

The mood created by the author is showing how Cuban's lived and about their culture and how they lived. Some people from other cultures could be different and don't care about their cultures, while some people do care about their culture like Narciso's parents. The author emphasizes the importance of respecting one's culture and not trying to be a different culture. This highlights the significance of heritage and traditions in shaping individuals and communities. It underscores the value of cultural identity and the need to preserve and honor it.

The mood created in the memoir is happiness and gratitude. Narciso is grateful of his parents for moving to @LOCATION1, and still give him warm happy feeling of a house in Cuba. His parents passed down their culture to him and he is happy that they did. Narciso is glad to have lived in the home that they did, and all the opportunities that he had as a child. He is grateful that his family always got together and had a feast with Cuban music, activities, and food. His parents gave up their jobs and had to start their lives over entirely. Narciso is also grateful that he learned the real definition of "family". He is also very grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. Additionally, he appreciates the strong sense of community and support that he experienced growing up in @LOCATION1. He cherishes the memories of family gatherings filled with laughter and love, and he is thankful for the values and traditions that his parents instilled in him. Narciso's gratitude extends to the opportunities and experiences that shaped him into the person he is today, and he will always hold his upbringing in @LOCATION1 close to his heart.

The mood definitely helps you feel and comprehend the story better. The mood is a mixture of both happy and sad because of the way the author states his ideas. For example, the sentence "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" makes me feel sad because he grew up and everything is just memories now but he keeps those happy memories. Most of other ideas like "I will be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" also carry the same reasons for being happy or sad. However statements like "My mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" makes me feel happy that his parents were so determind. Overall the main idea is remembering the good and bad times of his life and the mood for this idea is happy/sad.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" he/she incorporated love and passion into the mood. You can tell this by how fondly and strongly Narciso talks about some things. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm houses." In this one sentence alone, you could feel Narciso's passion and love for this home of theirs. Narciso puts a great deal of love and thankfulness into paragraph when talking about his/her parents. "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'... I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." These two sentences are most likely the strongest in Narciso's memoir, these two are also the ones filled with the most passion and meaning. As you can see, in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", the mood Narciso puts in it is love and passion.

In the excerpt, the mood created by the author is love. Love for family and love for each other. The author talks about his parents in a loving and respectful way, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The author describes all his parents went through to make their own and his life better. In doing so they turned an apartment into a place of love and caring that he will never forget and more importantly passed this love onto him. The author also talks about his "family" and the love shared between them, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." The author's "family" wasn't completely blood-related. Many people were friends but very close friends that have become like family and were always welcomed. Finally, the author talks about his community, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." No matter what nationality they were, the community was very close together and understanding. It was these basic principles of friendship, trust, love, and caring that were passed onto the author of this excerpt by a variety of people and give the excerpt a mood of love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful and fortunate. Narciso Rodriguez talks about being so fortunate to have his parents and his heritage of being Cuban. From paragraph 1, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Rodriguez is saying that he was so happy and lucky to have his parents as parents which is the main mood of the memoir. Another mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir is happiness. He makes the story happy by saying how great it was to grow up with his family. He also says that his family was a lot of people in his neighborhood as well. Rodriguez is happy to have a great family. From paragraph 2, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." These are two moods created by Rodriguez in his memoir.  In conclusion, Narciso Rodriguez's memoir conveys a sense of gratitude and happiness, highlighting the importance of family and heritage in shaping his life.

The author generally stayed in one mood. The mood portrayed in the story was family and friends are very important and they help shape who you will be in the future. This is why the author stressed how thankful he was that his family had come to @LOCATION1 to make him a better life and that his friends came over to share their culture. Also the author emphasized the importance of remembering his Cuban blood and culture even in @LOCATION1. This is why he says "...and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." The author also mentioned that a home is where great memories are made and where you grow up, emphasizing the significance of never forgetting one's roots.
The mood that the author creates in this story is a sad one. But it is also hopeful, as the guy in it is getting a new home and a new life without his parents.

The mood in the memoir that the author creates is very warm and relaxed, evoking feelings of nostalgia and comfort. The author's depiction of his parents as selfless individuals who always put their children first paints a picture of love and dedication. The description of the home, with its colorful interior and vibrant atmosphere, brings to mind images of a cozy and inviting space where family gathers and memories are made. The mention of cooking with colorful ingredients and the sound of music in the background adds to the sensory experience, making the reader feel as though they are right there in the moment. Overall, the mood of the memoir is one of love, warmth, and happiness, making the reader reflect on their own cherished memories and the special moments shared with their loved ones.

The memoir highlights the strong bond Narciso had with his family and his Cuban heritage, portraying a vibrant and loving atmosphere in his childhood home in Newark, New Jersey. It conveys the message that a house is more than just a physical structure; it is a place filled with cherished memories and connections that shape one's identity and sense of belonging. The upbeat and happy mood of the memoir reflects the warmth and positivity of Narciso's upbringing, emphasizing the importance of family, love, and cultural roots in shaping one's life journey.

The author's memoir reflects a somber and challenging mood as she recalls her difficult upbringing due to her parents' constant moving. By the age of twenty-seven, she finds herself living in a cramped one-room apartment with her family, highlighting the struggles they faced. Racism was prevalent in her upbringing, adding to the hardships she endured. Despite these challenges, the author's parents instilled in her valuable lessons, such as cooking and the importance of love. These experiences shaped her perspective on life and relationships, showcasing the resilience and strength that carried her through tough times.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy, enjoyable, and worth living. I say happy because they had family to be with, and other friends to help them if anything. I say enjoyable because the author talks about how they (main character) had the first birthday and first friend. I would enjoy all my birthdays if I was that person and also my first friend. I also said worth living because they had food on their table everyday. And nothing in the memoir said anything about struggling. This is why I explain the mood as happy, enjoyable, and worth living. The author's recount of their experiences paints a picture of a life filled with joy, companionship, and contentment, making every moment worth cherishing.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is one of love, care, and gratitude towards friends and family. The author portrays his mother as a compassionate and generous person who always offers help to those in need, reflecting a sense of kindness and empathy. Additionally, the author expresses a deep sense of gratitude for the support and care he has received from his friends and community. This mood of thankfulness is evident in the author's reflections on his life and the positive impact he has made on others. Overall, the memoir conveys a heartfelt appreciation for the love and support that surrounds the author, highlighting the importance of small acts of kindness and the profound impact they can have on one's life.

In this memoir, the author creates a mood of love. He expresses deep appreciation for his parents and all they have sacrificed to come to @LOCATION1. The warmth of the kitchen, filled with love and culture, is described through the aroma of their cooking and the music that fills the space. The author emphasizes the closeness of his family and friends, considering them all as one big family. They support each other and keep their arms and doors open to those in need, creating a strong sense of love and unity. This mood of love permeates the author's memories and experiences, shaping his perspective on family and relationships.

The author of this memoir created a mood that emphasizes the sacrifices and love of family. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved," highlighting the immense sacrifices parents make for their children. "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'," suggesting that family goes beyond blood relations and embodies love and support. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," indicating that the true essence of a home lies in the bonds and memories created within its walls. These sentiments evoke a deep appreciation for the profound impact and importance of family in one's life.

The mood created by this author is clearly grateful. The author shows how he (Narciso) could never stop saying thank you. He honestly loved the feeling his mom and dad made him have and all the things they did for him. By what the parents did by moving into a place to call home for Narciso made his mood forever endlessly grateful. By Narciso's mood being grateful I mean endlessly thankful for all that he has thanks to his parents. In this short autobiography, Narciso creates the reader to feel and know he is happy with the life he has. As this short story creates the mood of being grateful. You understand how he feels as you read many times throughout this article, "I will always be grateful to my parents..."

The mood set by the author in the memoir is a warm and inviting one, emphasizing the importance of family, friendships, and generosity. The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful, joyful, and loving. The author expresses gratitude towards their parents for their love and sacrifice, stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Despite living in a simple house, the author found joy in the passionate Cuban music that filled the air and the aromas of the kitchen. This joyful atmosphere was a result of the author's cultural upbringing. Additionally, the author highlights the loving nature of their home, where their parents welcomed anyone in need of help. The author fondly recalls, "My parents kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Despite facing challenges such as segregation, the author's home remained a place of happiness and love.

In the memoir, the author created a very upbeat mood. He clearly is very grateful for his family, and had a happy childhood. He pointed out the parts of his home and situation that could have been negative for him while growing up, but then he canceled those negative things out by noting the positive aspects of each situation. For example, in the memoir he wrote about how his family had immigrated to the United States, and how they had good jobs in Cuba, but then had to start all over with low-paying jobs once they got here. He said that this was hard for them, but he found a positive way to look at the situation. He did this by writing about how his parent's situation taught them and him to always work hard, and never give up. So overall, he made what could have been a depressing story, have an upbeat and happy mode. He even made the story teach you a lesson about hard work and the importance of family and giving to others. Additionally, he highlighted how their tight-knit family dynamic allowed them to support each other through the challenges they faced, fostering a sense of unity and resilience. This positive outlook on life and focus on the silver linings in difficult situations is truly inspiring and serves as a valuable lesson for readers to always find the good in every circumstance.

The mood created by the author of the memoir is cozy and family oriented. From the very beginning, the author describes the home as more of a way of life than a physical space. The author's "parents created our traditional Cuban home, part of which was the kitchen" (@NUM1). Here, the home is described even more as a part of the family, less is a building. To enhance the feeling of family, the author includes stories of hospitality: "My parents always kept their arms and their door to the many people he considered family" (@NUM2). Hospitality is one of the best qualities you need to make a house a home and the author really stretches that. The mood created by the author of the memoir is cozy and family oriented.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, creates a very happy mood in his memoir. One reason the mood is happy is because of the setting. Narciso describes his house and says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the back-drop to life in our warm home." The author describes a home filled with many good friends and good memories. Another reason is how grateful the author sounds. It says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." While they had to leave everything behind they did it for their kids and for a new life. The author is happy that they did. Also, the author credits the house with giving him a family. Narciso says, "It was here that I learned the real definition of the word 'family.' And for this, I will be forever grateful." Narciso learned a lot in this house and is very happy for that. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, he creates a very happy mood.

Based on this memoir, the mood created by the author is one of deep gratitude and admiration for his parents and the life they provided for him. He reflects on the sacrifices they made and the love they showed, acknowledging that their actions were truly courageous. The author also highlights the passion and beauty of Cuban music, a central part of his upbringing that brought warmth and joy to their home. Through these details, the author conveys a sense of love, appreciation, and nostalgia for the past that shaped him into the person he is today.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez was happy and thankful. His parents taught him many things about their Cuban background, like cooking and music. His parents gave up many things to comfort Narciso and make him at home. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." His parents turned their house into a home for other people as well. "My parents always kept their arms and door open to the many people we considered family." Narciso's parents would take in anybody that needed a place to stay until they got back on their feet. Narciso's parents were very loving to the community and helped out as much as they could in making that place a home. Their kindness and generosity touched the lives of many, creating a warm and welcoming atmosphere for all who entered their doors.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, the author paints a picture of a childhood filled with both hardship and joy. This sense of unity and support from those around him brought a sense of happiness to his life. The author's gratitude shines through as he reflects on the sacrifices his parents made to provide him with a better future. Overall, the memoir captures a blend of seriousness, happiness, and thankfulness, offering a heartfelt glimpse into the author's formative years.

@PERSON1's mood was happy and grateful because he had his family together, and his parents were embracing their culture. He felt grateful for the opportunities and freedom they had in their new life, compared to the limitations they faced in Cuba. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, the mood and feeling of her home and community is a happy and heartwarming situation. Most people who would live in a tiny apartment in the city would say that it was too small and cramped, while they wished for a mansion on the ocean, but Narciso was perfectly happy being in that environment. The way she described it, there were always great smells, wonderful music, and great people around all of the time. Narciso said the man people who contributed the most to her wonderful experience in New Jersey were her parents. They supported and cared for her at the same time they were struggling for money. They never showed sadness and they loved and cared for her. Even though Narciso lived in a small apartment in the city, she and her family show that you can make the best out of any situation. The warmth and love of her family and community made their home a place filled with happiness and contentment.

In the memoir, Rodriguez reflects on his childhood and the sense of family he experienced growing up. He emphasizes that family is not solely defined by blood relations, but also by the community and culture that surrounds us. He fondly recalls the mix of Italian, Spanish, and Cuban cultures in his neighborhood, where differences were put aside to create a strong sense of unity and love. Rodriguez's memoir is a tribute to the lessons he learned about love and family from his upbringing, highlighting the importance of embracing diversity and building connections with those around us. Through his heartfelt storytelling, he conveys the enduring impact of his childhood home and neighborhood on his understanding of family and community.

In the memoir "@PERSON1 Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives by @PERSON1, the mood is a very important part of the story. The mood in this memoir is definitely thankfulness. The first reason for why the mood of this story is thankfulness is because @PERSON1 is thankful for his Cuban heritage. @PERSON1 shows his love for his heritage by stating "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills". @PERSON1 is very thankful that he has these skills from his great culture. The second reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his home. "...Formed the backdrop to life in our warm home", @PERSON1 writes in his memoir. This quote shows that @PERSON1 is thankful for a nice place to call his home. The final reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his hardworking parents. "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly," he comments. This undeniably shows the author's great respect for his parents and all they have to offer for him to be happy and healthy. Thankfulness is a mood that suits this memoir very well, and the pride and gratefulness that the author shows for his heritage, home, and parents is wonderful.

The mood created by the author in "Narciso Rodriguez" is very calm and happy. The author portrays a sense of peace and contentment throughout the story, highlighting moments of growth and love within a family. Celebrations and gatherings with friends and family are described with warmth and affection. The final line, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple little house into a home," encapsulates the sentiment of love and unity that runs through the entire narrative. It is a beautiful depiction of the power of family to create a sense of belonging and happiness.

The author's memoir is filled with a happy, grateful, and appreciative mood. He expresses his enjoyment in everything he does, showing a sense of happiness throughout his experiences. Moreover, the author consistently expresses gratitude towards his parents, admiring their hard work and sacrifices to provide a better life for their family. The admiration and appreciation he feels towards his parents are evident in his writing, as he acknowledges their efforts and expresses his thanks for all they have done. This overall tone of happiness, gratitude, and appreciation sets the mood for the author's heartfelt memoir.

In Narciso's memoir, I feel joy because his parents were able to survive and thrive in their new environment. The Rodriguez family's open arms and open door policy created a sense of community and belonging for all who came their way. This generosity and sense of family solidarity is truly heartwarming and inspiring.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of gratitude and happiness. The author's mood throughout the memoir is one of admiration and thankfulness for the sacrifices and hard work of his parents, who provided him with a better life and set a positive example for him to follow.

In this excerpt from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by Narciso Rodriguez, the author expresses his deep gratitude towards his parents for their love, sacrifice, strength, and perseverance. Heartwarming. That is the mood that Narciso Rodriguez creates in his memoir Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives. Narciso talks of the passionate Cuban culture, his welcoming home, and his caring and selfless parents. Narciso starts out the story, describing his home. He explains that it was filled with Cuban culture - food, music, and all. Narciso states, "My parents both shared a love of cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." That description allows the reader to picture the warm culture of his childhood home.  Then, Narciso explains that his home was always open to friends, family, and neighbors. He explains that they were all united because the country was filled with racism. To overcome that, they needed to stick together. Narciso states, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." That just invites the reader in.  Lastly, Narciso explains his gratitude he has towards his parents. He states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." His gratitude and love towards his parents just warm the reader's heart. Narciso Rodriguez truly and honestly creates a heartwarming mood in his memoir Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives. May his message be carried on for centuries.

Narciso Rodriguez, a memoir about growing up in a new environment with his family, exudes a definite mood of happiness. Throughout the memoir, the author portrays a positive and joyful atmosphere that surrounded his upbringing. From the way his parents incorporated their Cuban heritage into their home with food, music, family gatherings, and celebrations, to the constant presence of loved ones like surrogate grandparents, cousins, and aunts and uncles, there was always a sense of warmth and joy in their household. Narciso expresses his gratitude towards his parents for their love, strength, and perseverance, emphasizing the importance of friends and family in shaping his upbringing. This memoir beautifully captures the essence of a happy and loving family life, showcasing the power of love and togetherness in creating a nurturing environment for growth and happiness.

Home and family hold a special place in all of our hearts. The author's portrayal of his home as a warm and welcoming place filled with loved ones creates a sense of gratitude and contentment. He emphasizes that family goes beyond blood ties, highlighting the importance of the connections we build with those we love. Narciso Rodriguez expresses his deep appreciation for his parents, who made sacrifices to provide him with a better life, even if it meant leaving their own families behind. Their courage and selflessness are qualities he greatly admires. Through his words, the author reflects on the love and support he has received from his family, and how his Hispanic heritage has shaped his identity. He leaves us with a sense of appreciation for the home and family that have nurtured him, showing that love knows no bounds when it comes to those we hold dear.

The author creates the mood of friendliness in the memoir by depicting how different cultures in their neighborhood come together in solidarity and friendship, despite segregation in other areas. This sense of unity and camaraderie among the residents highlights the warm and welcoming atmosphere that permeates their community. Overall, the author effectively conveys a mood of friendliness that is evident in the interactions and relationships within the neighborhood.

The mood created in this memoir is excellent. For example in paragraph one, it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This gives me the feeling of thankfulness and to really admire what my parents have done for me. Another example is in paragraph two, it says "It was here I learned the real definition of family." This quote makes me feel so happy that I have a family that supports me and is always there for me. This memoir really changed how I look at things and made me realize how thankful I am to have my family. It's truly a heartwarming account that resonates with the importance of familial love and support in shaping our lives.

The way the author describes his family and his home gives the memoir a very warm, happy, and pleasant mood. He had a very warm tone when he talks about how much love there was in his house. "Here, the innocence of childhood, and the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The mood of the memoir was happy uplifting when he talked about how his parents helped others and they always had people in their house. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." The mood of the memoir was brought to life when the author described the rich culture in his home. "traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen.... Unwittingly passed on to me they're rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." I think the addition in the parentheses make it light and airy. His tone is thrilled and thankful for his rich culture. The author's tone was very sweet, I think, when thanking his parents. "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me... and the demonstration of how important family and friends are.... and these teachings have been the basis of my life." The mood of the memoir is warm, happy, and sweet, thanks to the author. The warmth and love in the author's family and home create a joyful and inviting atmosphere that resonates throughout the memoir, highlighting the importance of generosity, family, and cultural traditions in shaping his life and values.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, creates a mood of hardship, and gratefulness. "After living for a year in a furnished one-room apartment, 2-year-old Rawedia and twenty-seven-year-old Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon call home." The memoir depicts hardship as the family moved from Cuba to a new location, leaving everything behind to start a new life in a small apartment.   The memoir also conveys gratefulness, as Narciso is appreciative of his family's sacrifices for his future and their unwavering love. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The story is a heartwarming account of a loving family who are thankful for having a place they can call home.

The mood created in "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez is a profound sense of closeness and selflessness that so enriched Narciso's childhood. The mood created by Narciso comes from his memoir, in which he lived a poor life, but a life that was enriched by friends and family that had a very close bond, one that overcame racism and tough times. "All of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The mood created by Narciso displays how his community acted, and shows how close his friends and family were. It is a mood that helps readers understand Narciso's community. The mood created by Narciso is also one of selflessness, as Narciso describes his community as one of "honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily of their own kind, were clearly in need." In summary, the memoir paints a picture of a community bound by strong relationships and a willingness to help those in need, showcasing the beauty of closeness and selflessness.

@PERSON1 is a heartwarming short story about a boy who deeply appreciates his parents and the effort they put into making their new home in @LOCATION1 feel like their old home in Cuba. The boy expresses gratitude towards his parents for creating a familiar and comforting environment by decorating the house with Cuban memorabilia. He acknowledges the love and care his parents have shown by transforming a simple house into a place filled with memories and warmth. This story beautifully illustrates the importance of family and the feeling of belonging, no matter where life may take us.

In the excerpt of Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, a memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, there is a mood of fond recollection of a warm and loving environment, as well as a gratitude for the lessons learned in this environment. Narciso mentions how his parents created a home for him even though it meant making many sacrifices. He describes his small apartment as a "traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This quote is important because it begins the explanation of why his house gives him so many warm memories conveyed in his writing. Narciso explains how many people in his neighborhood are immigrants that come together, help one another, and form one big family. "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." Many people in his neighborhood joined Narciso's family for meals and this brought many of them closer. At the end of the memoir, Narciso explains how grateful he is that his parents gave up their lives in Cuba to give him a better chance in New York despite their hardships. This undeniable thankfulness is a large part of this memoir.

Narciso Rodriguez's memoir reflects his deep love and appreciation for his family and home. He emphasizes the sacrifices his parents made to provide him with a better life, moving to New Jersey for that purpose. Rodriguez expresses immense gratitude towards his parents for the opportunities they have given him. His memoir exudes positivity and highlights the happiness he feels when reminiscing about his home and the life his parents have created for him. Despite facing challenges, Rodriguez's memoir conveys a message of resilience and living life to the fullest, showcasing his profound sense of gratitude and love for his family.

In this memoir, there is more than one mood. There is love, friendship, and happiness Narciso expresses love for her parents and friends in paragraph. Narciso Rodriguez is thankful for what his parents gave him, thus that is the overlying mood in the memoir, being thankful. Even though he says that his parents had to leave behind "family, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Rodriguez is also thankful that his parents taught him selflessness and generosity. Overall, Rodriguez is thankful for his Cuban culture. Cuban culture encompasses cooking and music, but most importantly, family, having nothing to do with being a blood relative, but the fact that you have respect and love for everyone. The mood of this memoir is being thankful and is presented in all these different ways.

The @CAPS1 that the author created in the memoir was an uplifting one. The mood of the excerpt is very bright. The author describes her risk taking, loving parents. The author describes the many things her parents have given to her. "Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home... As you can see, the author, Narciso Rodriguez, describes her young life and home with happiness and gratefulness. This is all generously spoken within the depths of the excerpt. Many authors enjoy using these tones to express their own personal feelings and opinions about the matter. In this case, the author wanted to express joy in her writing. The warmth and love of her childhood home shine through in her words, painting a vivid picture of a happy and cherished upbringing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is interesting. His parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living in a furnished one-room apartment for a year, twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria and twenty-seven-year-old @ORGANIZATION1 could afford to move into a modest three-room apartment that would soon become home. In 1961, the author was born into this simple house situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. The author's description of their modest beginnings sets a tone of resilience and determination, highlighting the humble yet hopeful atmosphere in which he was raised. The contrast between their humble beginnings and the aspirations for a better life sets the stage for a compelling narrative of growth, challenges, and ultimately, triumph.

The mood in this memoir is one of gratitude. Narciso expresses his appreciation for his parents who sacrificed everything for his better future. As I sit here, lost in my memories, a sense of nostalgia washes over me. I can vividly recall the laughter of my childhood, the warmth of family gatherings, and the innocence of youth. Each memory is like a precious gem, carefully tucked away in the recesses of my mind. I can almost feel the sun on my skin as I reminisce about carefree days spent playing in the backyard, the smell of freshly cut grass lingering in the air.  The memories of holidays past bring a bittersweet smile to my face. I can still taste the homemade cookies and hear the sound of carols filling the air. The joy and togetherness of those moments are etched into my heart, creating a warm glow that never fades.  But amidst the happy recollections, there are also memories tinged with sadness. The loss of loved ones, the ache of goodbyes, and the passage of time all leave their mark. Yet even in these moments of sorrow, there is a sense of gratitude for the experiences that have shaped me into who I am today.  As I delve deeper into the tapestry of my past, I am reminded of the richness of life – the ups and downs, the laughter and tears, the love and loss. Each memory is a thread that weaves together the fabric of my existence, creating a story that is uniquely mine. And as I reflect on these memories, I am filled with a profound sense of appreciation for the journey that has brought me to this moment.

The author was likely describing his happy childhood. He loved his home, his parents' cooking, and the music they enjoyed. He was grateful for his parents' care and selflessness. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso projects a very grateful, thankful, and optimistic mood. The mood created by the author in this memoir is both happy and uplifting but also sad. Another example of happiness is when he describes his community of united and hard-working immigrants, "In our neighborhood all of those cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." An example of sadness is when it says, "The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved." In the non--fiction memoir "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso talks about his life growing up, his home, and the people around him. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This gives the memoir a sweet mood, the author shows his happiness and gratefulness for everything his parents had done for him. In 1956 Narciso Rodriguez's parents arrived in the United States and bought a small apartment. In 1961, Narciso was born and began his life in this new environment. His parents, who loved to cook, filled the air with the passionate sounds of Cuban music as they prepared meals. Despite coming from different backgrounds, the sense of family was strong in their home. People from various cultures and customs would come together, offering support and care to one another. Guests were welcomed into their home, staying as they navigated through life's challenges. Narciso credits his parents for teaching him the true essence of love and family, creating a home filled with cherished memories that he will forever hold dear.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", the author created a happy tone throughout the whole story. Narcisco talked about how when he moved to @LOCATION1 he moved into a three-bedroom apartment. Narciso was very grateful that his parents came to @LOCATION1 to help him make his home seem more like a traditional Cuban home. "It was a simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. The flavors of Cuba that filled the air and the laughter that echoed through the walls will forever be cherished, a testament to the power of a shared meal and the warmth of a welcoming home."

Growing up in a modest home in Newark, New Jersey, I learned the true importance of family and the power of turning a simple house into a warm and welcoming home. It was within these walls that I experienced moments of joy, sorrow, and everything in between, surrounded by the love and support of my family. Despite the challenges we faced, we always found a way to make the best of our circumstances and create a sense of belonging that transcended the physical structure of our house. Through our shared experiences and shared values, we built a strong foundation of love and unity that has stayed with me throughout my life. Looking back, I realize that it was not the size or grandeur of our home that mattered, but the relationships and memories we forged within its walls. In those moments, I learned that family is not defined by blood or DNA, but by the connections we create and the love we share. And it is this lesson that has guided me in my journey to create my own sense of home and family, no matter where life may take me.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, the mood of the story is a harmonious blend of love, generosity, and gratitude. The mood is very warm and welcoming. It starts off with a beautiful and culturally enriched apartment. The walls are adorned with colorful tapestries and the shelves are filled with intricate figurines from around the world. The air is filled with the aroma of delicious foods cooking in the kitchen, a blend of spices that transport you to distant lands.   As you settle in, the sound of music fills the room - a mix of traditional melodies and modern beats that create a vibrant and lively atmosphere. The laughter of friends and family adds to the warmth of the gathering, making you feel right at home.  But as the night goes on and the festivities wind down, there is a tinge of sadness in the air. The time has come for her parents to leave, to embark on a journey to make a better life for themselves. As they hug her tightly and promise to return soon, there is a sense of longing and loss that lingers in the room. Despite the sadness, there is also hope and determination in their eyes, a reminder that even as they part ways, they will always be connected by love and memories.  In the end, as the door closes behind them, the apartment may feel a bit emptier, but the spirit of togetherness and love that filled the space will always remain, a reminder of the bond that transcends distance and time.

The mood of the memoir is love. @PERSON1 and his family always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they consider family, knowing that they would do the same for them. Even though their neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States, they all cared for each other as if they were one family. Prior to moving to the United States, Narciso, Sr., had worked in the laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. They moved to the United States, leaving their good jobs, so that their son could live a better life. Narciso doesn't take this for granted. He engulfs them in a profusion of thanks. Throughout the memoir, the author constantly writes about all the caring and love in the lives of @PERSON1 and his family. Their story is a testament to the power of love and compassion, showing how even in the face of adversity, kindness and unity can prevail.

they'd sold what little furniture they'd possessed by then, including a small dining table, a couple of chairs, and a worn-out sofa. With these pieces gone, their living space felt emptier than ever. Fashion designer Narciso Rodriguez fondly recalls his childhood filled with a strong sense of family and community. Growing up in a neighborhood of immigrants, he witnessed people extending a helping hand to those in need, regardless of their background. This act of kindness was a beacon of light during a time of racial tension and segregation in the United States.   Within his own home, Rodriguez experienced the true meaning of family. His parents welcomed individuals who needed temporary shelter, believing that one day, they too may require assistance. This sense of solidarity and support created a warm and inviting atmosphere, where everyone was considered part of the family.  Rodriguez acknowledges the profound impact of these early lessons on the importance of friendship and family. Through his upbringing, he learned that family goes beyond blood relations and that having a network of supportive individuals is invaluable. The mood of his memoir reflects these core values of unity, compassion, and the strength found in communal bonds. Family and helping hands are not just concepts to Rodriguez; they are the guiding principles that shape his worldview and approach to life.

I am proud of my Cuban heritage and the strong relationship I have with my family. Growing up, I was surrounded by love, laughter, and unforgettable memories in Cuba. My parents worked hard to provide for our family, and we lived in a beautiful house filled with warmth and happiness.  Leaving Cuba was a difficult decision, as I had to say goodbye to the place I called home and the people I loved. However, coming to America opened up new opportunities for me and my family. Despite the challenges of adjusting to a new country, I am grateful for the experiences and friendships I have gained here.  Reflecting on my Cuban roots fills me with pride and nostalgia. The values instilled in me by my parents and the memories of my upbringing continue to shape who I am today. I am thankful for the strong foundation they have given me and the rich cultural heritage that will always be a part of me.

The mood in this memoir is happy. I think the mood is happy because Narciso Rodriguez was grateful for mostly everything in his life. A house is not a home without family, and a family is not a family without its trails, struggles, and happiness. The mood in the memoir was to show what family is, that its much more than blood. It's unity, friendship and laughter, its the tears, pain and heartache. Its about how you can start in the slums and work your way up but one thing is never going to change, and that's family. Home doesnt matter about the physical space of the dwelling, but about the relationships and memories you make there. Home is where unity, satisfaction, happpness, and imagination come together in one unorganized way, but it doesnt mean that it won't have trails like racism that almost every minority has to deal with even Narciso Rodriguez dealt with it. I deal with it to, I get called cracker and n**** on a daily baised, I dont know how I would get through it without family. Home is where we find solace and support in the face of adversity, where we draw strength and courage to face the challenges of the world. Family is the anchor that keeps us grounded and the light that guides us through the darkness. In the end, it is the love and bond we share with our family that truly makes a house a home.

In his memoir Home: Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez creates a warm, familial mood. Narciso's deep gratitude for his parents' decision to move to the United States has a large effect on the mood. He describes how brave his mother and father must have been to make the life-changing choice, and admits that "I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude." The author understands what a large, positive influence his parents have had on him, and his gratitude for his family contributes to the warm mood of the piece. Narciso's admiration for his family also develops the atmosphere of the memoir. He uses words like selfless and hardworking to describe his family, and tells them of his "admiration for strength and perseverance." Through his descriptions of the feats his parents have accomplished and the hardships they have had to endure, the author conveys his feeling of true admiration for his family to the reader. However, absolute love is the strongest emotion that the reader feels from the memoir. Narciso uses careful selection of what memories he writes in his memoir, along with the addition of passionate words like warm, gracious, honest, and close-knit to make the love within his family stand out. Although there were certainly fights within his family, he never mentions them, focusing instead on the underlying bond he felt with his relatives and how the warmth of his kitchen "filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." Narciso is passionate enough about the atmosphere within his family that he makes the gratitude, admiration, and love he feels for his relatives the focus of his memoir.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," he expresses gratitude and pride for his upbringing and family. He reflects on his humble beginnings in a one-room apartment in Cuba and the strong community bonds in Newark, New Jersey where his family resides. Narciso highlights the solidarity and friendships among Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants, emphasizing their honest and hardworking nature. He acknowledges the sacrifices his parents made, stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Moreover, he cherishes the memories of how his parents transformed their simple house into a warm and welcoming home. Narciso's journey from a modest background to becoming a renowned fashion designer is a testament to the values instilled in him by his family and community.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez a mood is created. Rodriguez remembers his home in a refreshed way. Narciso is very thankful for his parents' immigration struggle and says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In the memoir, the author portrays a neighborhood where everyone treated each other like family, despite facing financial struggles as immigrants. Narciso's parents, who had prestigious jobs in Cuba, had to take on menial work in @LOCATION2. They were always ready to assist their family members in times of need. Narciso's family, although poor, embraced their situation and maintained their Cuban culture through music and cuisine. The entire community, bonded by a sense of unity, thrived despite limited resources. In their corner of Newark, New Jersey, family was not solely defined by blood relations; rather, it encompassed the close-knit network of individuals who supported each other through hardships.

In the memoir, the mood created by the author at the beginning is hard, reflecting the challenges faced due to overt racism towards Spanish, Black, and Asian immigrants. This sets a tone of struggle and adversity. However, as the story progresses, a shift occurs, and a happy mood emerges as the neighborhood comes together in solidarity and friendship, transcending cultural differences. This unity brings a sense of joy and optimism to the narrative, showcasing the power of community and togetherness in overcoming hardships. Overall, the contrasting moods of hardship and happiness portrayed in the memoir provide a nuanced depiction of the author's experiences and the resilience of the human spirit in the face of adversity.

@ORGANIZATION1 reminisces about his childhood in a small house in Newark, painting a picture of joy and warmth. In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, it shows the story of how a young boy's home and parents have changed his life forever. Originally from Cuba, Narciso's parents immigrated to the United States in 1956. They started off in a small apartment then later getting the money to move into a "simple house." "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relation." Narciso believes that some of the most loving families are not related. The mood in this memoir is inspiring to the narrator. This allows the reader to feel such love and happiness which is being expressed. "They came selflessly as many immigrants do to give their children a better life." The narrator is explaining what courage it took for his parents to make such an adjustment for the sake of his own happiness. Overall, the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is a story full of love and should be told for generations to come. The main lesson here is don't take your family for granted, the narrator is forever grateful that his parents "turned this simple house into a home."

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," different moods are portrayed. One prevalent mood is happiness, as the author expresses joy in his surroundings and family, stating, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Another mood evident in the memoir is enjoyment, as the author relishes family moments and the constant presence of loved ones, noting, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." What is a memoir? A memoir is of writing someone's own feelings and experiences during their life. This memoir by Narciso Rodriguez tells of her life in her simple home in Newark, New Jersey. Throughout the memoir Rodriguez sits a distinct mood of love and care, which she learned from her parents back in her childhood. The mood is mainly set by the memories of her environment, friends, and culture. All of these things are described by Rodriguez to make you feel the mood she expresses. The mood of love and care is incorporated into the memories of her childhood, beginning from the time she was born. Rodriguez begins to draw the mood in paragraph two by describing her home that was made into a traditional Cuban home by her parents. She describes the "rich culinary skills... Passionate Cuban music... And the congregation of family and friends." @CAPS1, she begins to describe the love of her friends and neighbors, who she felt, were family. Last, Rodriguez describes the influence her Cuban culture has had on her. She talks about how her parents helped others of their kind which made her what she is today. Additionally, Rodriguez reminisces about the smells of her mother's cooking that filled their home, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. She also recalls the lively conversations and laughter that echoed through their house, emphasizing the importance of family and community in shaping her values. Moreover, Rodriguez fondly remembers the traditional Cuban celebrations and customs that were a significant part of her upbringing, instilling in her a deep appreciation for her heritage. These memories highlight the love and care that permeated every aspect of Rodriguez's life, making her memoir a heartfelt tribute to her roots and the people who influenced her journey.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is a loving mood. Narciso's parents came all the way from Cuba to give him a better life. "... regularly joined us at our table." But in this new country, his parents were struggling personally and financially, but even though they started life all over again. Their love for each other and their unwavering faith in a brighter future bound them together, providing the strength needed to overcome the challenges they faced.

Rawedia Maria and Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon call home. Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. In the memoir Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez described their childhood home. The author creates a mood in this memoir. The author sets many moods for the reader in his memoir from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives. The first and most dominant mood is a sense of family or friendship. The author constantly describes how his family's generosity made his apartment into a friendly place with the constant coming and going of relatives, distant and close. Next the author installed a sense of warmth. The very idea of this family moving from cuba into this three room apartment for their son really gives any reader some sense of warmth. Finally the author gives us a Sense of culture. As early as paragraph @NUM1 the author writes..."My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful. Passionate Cuban music (which I still adore today) filled the air..." In these ways, the author reaches out to his readers with the mood of friendship, warmth, and culture to give us a taste of his life with his adoring parents in this small three room house he called home. The author's vivid descriptions and personal anecdotes create a compelling narrative that immerses readers in the unique atmosphere of his childhood home, evoking a deep sense of nostalgia and appreciation for the bonds of family and culture.

@ORGANIZATION1 creates a warm, comforting mood in a piece of Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives. He does this by explaining what goes on in a positive light. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congression of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm homes." This quote uses words like celebrations and warm to show that this place was a comforting place that always had a great time. This shows how Narciso Rodriguez created this warm, comforting mood. The details provided in the text evoke a sense of nostalgia and happiness, highlighting the importance of family, friends, and joyful gatherings in creating a cozy and inviting atmosphere in our homes. The use of positive language further enhances the feeling of warmth and comfort, making the reader feel like they are part of a welcoming and loving environment.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", the mood created by the author is gratefull and family. Throughout the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez talks about his life growing up. Readers read things like: "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage," and "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." @CAPS1, towards the end, the author explains that he is very grateful to have his parents: "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice.", and "in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generousity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." @CAPS2, Narciso Rodriguez was greatly influenced by his family during his childhood, and his memoir shows that along with how grateful he will always be. The love and sacrifice of his parents, as well as the lessons of generosity and the importance of family and friends, have shaped Narciso Rodriguez into the person he is today.

There is a very distinct mood set by Narciso in this passage. He talks about Faith, love, courage, and just the overall niceness of his home and community. He is grateful for his home, his family, and his community, of course he "groups" the last two together because of the deep, emotional way they all felt. Gratitude is one thing so he doesn't have.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was one of warmth and inclusivity. The author's experiences highlight the importance of love, community, and resilience in shaping one's sense of family and belonging.

In the memoir, the author expresses his gratitude multiple times for the memories, cooking skills, and Cuban music that his parents passed on to him. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood created by the story was complex. It was a mix of somber, grateful, and proud emotions. The somber mood was evident as Narciso and his parents faced financial struggles and cultural hardships after leaving their home to come to the United States. However, amidst the challenges, there was also a sense of gratitude. Narciso was thankful for his parents' sacrifices and teachings, which enabled him to have a better life. In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez portrays a happy mood. First he expresses gratitude for the rich culinary skills and love of cooking passed down to him by his parents. Immigrants from Cuba to the United States usually had to undergo a tough transition. It took buckets full of courage and motivation to get through this huge transition. Also, the satisfaction mood comes out when Narciso talks about how fortunate he is that his parents were willing to take the risk of moving to the United States to give him a better life. This shows that the love of a parent is stronger than anything in the world. Another mood is relief. For example, Narciso is relieved that his family made it to the United States safely and sound. This article is a perfect example that family is all you have in the end and that no matter what, they are there for you. The strong bond and support of family can help overcome even the toughest of transitions and challenges.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our lives by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a mood for the story. The mood for his story is bittersweet. Another way Rodriguez makes the mood bittersweet is by talking about his parents. Rodriguez writes, "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Rodriguez writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." The mood of the author of the story is happy and sad. When I read "Narciso Rodriguez," I thought the mood was warm and thoughtful. The mood created by the author in the memoir is very happy and appreciative of what he once had. An example of appreciating his life is where he states, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Another example of the mood being happy is where it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows how happy he was because of how much his parents loved him. My third example in the story is when the author states, "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This shows that the writer appreciates how much his parents cared for others, and how much others cared for them. My fourth and final example is, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant having to leave behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This statement shows how happy and appreciative the author is, because of how the author's parents left everything to give their kids a great life. And those were for specific examples of how the mood created by the author was very happy and appreciative in the memoir. The author's joyful and grateful recounting of his past experiences with his loving and selfless parents truly conveys a mood of happiness and appreciation throughout the memoir.

The mood created in the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez From, Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by the author is all about love and happiness. The memoir is mostly about family and childhood memories. Narciso Rodriguez is very gracious and compassionate, and he will never forget the monumental risk his parents made to leave everything behind to come to America so he could have a better life. In the story "Narciso Rodriguez From Home: "The Blueprints of Our Lives," the little girl initially struggles to see her one-bedroom apartment as a home. She believes that moving into a larger, three-bedroom apartment will finally make her feel like she has a true home. Throughout the story, she grapples with understanding love and how to care for others.  However, by the end of the narrative, the little girl has a newfound realization about love. She acknowledges the efforts her parents put into transforming their simple house into a warm and loving home. She reflects on the memories created within those walls and appreciates the love and care that have made their house a true home.  In the end, the little girl learns that a home is not defined by its size or grandeur but by the love and warmth shared within its walls. She now understands the true meaning of love and the importance of caring for others, realizing that her parents have created a home filled with love and memories that she will always cherish.

Narciso Rodriguez's @CAPS1 from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, creates a very optimistic mood. I was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and when I celebrated my first birthday. I was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of family. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I never forget this house, where every corner held memories of laughter, shared meals, and the bond of those who had found solace in each other's company. The lessons of compassion and unity that I absorbed in that kitchen have stayed with me, shaping the way I view the world and the relationships I cultivate. The simplicity and warmth of that house continue to inspire me to create spaces of belonging and acceptance wherever I go. In that humble abode, I found not just a physical shelter, but a sanctuary of the heart that taught me the true essence of home.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by Rodriguez is shocking. First, on page 23, Rodriguez wrote, "I would not know my 'real' grandparents until they leave Cuba." This is important because early in the memoir she mentioned her surrogate grandparents, Sergio and Edelmira, who came over for dinner. In conclusion, in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by her is shocking when her real grandparents finally come to visit in 1970. She wanted to convey this to teach the reader about the true meaning of family.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of love and happiness, highlighting the sacrifices made by his parents for their child's well-being.
