He is very grateful for his parents bringing him to @LOCATION1 so he could have a good life, even though they had to leave their life in Cuba to come here for him. This sense of gratitude and love permeates the memoir, creating a warm and cheerful tone throughout.

The mood created by this memoir is a relaxed caring kind of mood. Several parts of this work emphasize this mood. The author often writes about how he loves his parents for their selflessness. This emphasizes the mood, and he repeats it many times and the repetition helps build mood as well. A final thing that helps the mood is how he describes how everyone in his neighborhood was kind to each other. In conclusion, there are many things in this work that emphasize a relaxed, caring mood. The overall tone of the memoir is one of appreciation and warmth, highlighting the importance of love and kindness in the author's life.

Within the walls of Narciso, her young parents created their traditional home, with the heart of the household being the kitchen. Both parents shared cooking duties, passing on their rich culinary skills to Narciso, who developed a love for cooking. Despite living in a neighborhood primarily inhabited by Spanish and Italian immigrants during a time of racism, Narciso's parents selflessly sacrificed their own comforts for the sake of giving their children a better life. Leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in their home country, they journeyed to a new land, facing numerous challenges along the way. Through these memories, Narciso cherishes the resilience and determination her family exhibited, knowing the hardships they overcame to provide her with a brighter future.

The mood created by the author was love from his family. The author describes "a love of Cuban cooking which is still with me today" and how "passionate Cuban music which I still adore today." The author got this love from his parents. Another way the author created the mood of love was by talking about how his "parents always kept their arms and door open." I know that it takes a lot to be able to let anyone into your home. The author is speaking very lovingly at this point in the story. The author also says that he "will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice." This also sets the mood of the story because they are talking about a loving relationship. The mood that the author set during the story was love. I think that this was a really good mood to set in a story. The love and warmth shared within the family truly shine through the author's words, creating a heartfelt and touching narrative that resonates with readers on a deep emotional level.

Narciso Rodriguez expresses his deep gratitude towards his parents in his memoir, emphasizing their strength and perseverance. He acknowledges the sacrifices they made for him and how they created a loving and supportive home for him. Rodriguez repeatedly thanks his parents for all they have done, highlighting the admiration he holds for them. Through his storytelling, the author conveys a mood of profound gratefulness towards his family, painting a picture of the significant impact his parents had on shaping his life and instilling in him a sense of appreciation for their unwavering support.

In this excerpt from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, @PERSON1 talks about the true meaning of "family" and the mood of gratitude is established. "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills... Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." In this passage, @PERSON2 is establishing his gratitude for the cultures of his family. He is grateful for the food and music that has wound its way into his present day life. My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships. Their sacrifices were immense, and I am forever grateful for the love and dedication they showed in creating a new life for our family. Their strength and resilience have shaped me into the person I am today, and I will always carry their legacy with me, honoring the values they instilled in me.

The warmth in the family described in the story is truly unique and special. The happiness, selflessness, and gratitude that the author's parents embody are truly admirable. Their willingness to take in others into their small apartment shows a level of generosity that is truly heartwarming. The simple act of celebrating the author's first birthday with such comfort and love speaks volumes about the kind of environment they have created. This sense of warmth and care is what the author seems to be striving to convey in his storytelling. The importance of these values shines through in the way he depicts his family life, emphasizing the beauty of selflessness and gratitude in creating a happy and fulfilling life.

The mood in this passage reflects Narciso Rodriguez's strong sense of pride in his Cuban nationality and his close-knit family ties. He openly discusses his background and upbringing, highlighting his roots in Cuba and his current home in America. Rodriguez also shares fond memories of his childhood and the tight-knit community of Cubans and Hispanics in his neighborhood. His love for his family, especially his spouse, is evident in his conversations. Overall, the passage conveys a warm and nostalgic feeling, emphasizing the importance of cultural identity and family connections in Rodriguez's life.

The mood in the memoir is grateful. It is grateful in a few ways. One way is in paragraph six he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." This shows that he is grateful toward his parents because they moved to the US from Cuba. Another way is in paragraph eight he says "my parents both shared cooking duties an unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I admired to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This shows that he is grateful toward his parents because of their Cuban culture and specifically their cooking skills being passed on to him. Those are some reasons why the mood of the memoir is grateful.

In "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful. Narciso is thankful for his parents support and love. When he talks about how he feels about his parents, he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM1). The words "grateful for their love and sacrifice" demonstrates that through his whole life they were there for him. They didnt just tell her what to do, they showed her. When he talks about the lessons he has learned from his parents, he says "They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM1). The words "basis of my life" demonstrates that they taught him how to live (the essentials to living). They also showed him the meaning of family. He doesn't just think family is blood related, "It was here when I learned the real definition of "family"" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM4). The words "definition of family" demonstrates that he is thankful for them teaching him what family means to them. In conclusion, the mood of this passage is grateful.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy one because Narciso expressed contentment with her parents' actions and the peaceful neighborhood where everyone was willing to help those in need. The sense of community and support highlighted in the memoir contributes to the overall positive atmosphere depicted by the author. This happy mood is further emphasized by the author's gratitude towards her parents and the supportive environment they lived in.

The memoir looks back on his childhood, with fondness, so I'd call the mood wistful. Yes, the author creates a wistful mood by talking about his childhood home, friends, and family. But wistfulness only lasts until the end of the paragraph, after that it becomes a grateful mood where he's giving out thanks and describing what his parents went through. If it is possible to have two moods, then this memoir does. The moods are both wistful and grateful.

The author's gratitude extends to his parents, who made sacrifices for his well-being by uprooting their lives and moving to a new country. He also appreciates the support and love of his extended family and friends, who have become his surrogate family. Furthermore, he cherishes his Cuban culture, which shapes his identity and traditions. Overall, the author's memoir is a testament to his deep sense of gratitude for the people and influences that have enriched his life.

The mood that the author created in the memoir was a blend of sadness and happiness, keeping readers interested throughout. The title, "Narciso Rodriguez," added to the overall appeal of the book. The memoir evoked strong emotions and provided a compelling narrative that resonated with readers.

The mood created by the author is both sadness and love. At first, the mood the author created was sadness. In paragraph 1 it says "They struggled both personally and financially." Narciso explains the tragedies his parents had to face in order for him to live in his current location. So by reading the excerpt based on the poverty and struggles his family faced makes you feel sad for them. I also chose love. In the excerpt it states, "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family.' And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." In the excerpt, the author explains the love he learned to form for the "family" in the neighborhood. Therefore, that's why I think love is another mood created by the author. In this memoir, it talks about the true meaning of selflessness and a home. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Narciso Rodriguez, the author shows a very strong mood relating to the piece. The emotions used to create the mood include passion, unity, and gratitude. The mood of this memoir has lots of passion. Narciso talks about his family's passion for their Cuban heritage, and how they shared it with him. That was a big component of turning that house into a home, and therefore, part of the mood that Rodriguez wanted to represent. "... my young parents created our traditional Cuban home... love of cooking... passionate Cuban music..." (Rodriguez). I also could feel a sense of unity the author was trying to portray. ".. the congregation of family and friends..." The author mentions several times his parents and him were always letting distant relatives stay at the house, and many friends and family came and shared dinner with them. The author even describes his community as a "... a close-knit community..." (Rodriguez). Lastly, a sense of gratitude runs along the spine of this piece. The author notes his parents were a huge part of his life, exposing his to his culture, family and friends, and they home. He doesn't even have to write how grateful he is, it is so evident. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." (Rodriguez). The author created a mood filled with passion, unity, and gratitude. All of these emotions are evident in the text.

The mood @CAPS1 creates is happy. He had no negative comment about his parents or the way he grew up. His parents sacrificed everything for him so he can have a better life. Also, the feel of his home reflected on the mood. It was a warm and safe environment. In paragraph @NUM1 it states, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, the endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm house." @CAPS2 can really tell that he loved his home and family and the reflected upon the mood. The warm and safe environment of his home, filled with love and celebration, contributed to the overall happy mood portrayed in his narrative.

Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish-speaking individuals who looked out for one another as if we were all part of one big extended family. The bonds we formed were strong and enduring, based on shared experiences, mutual support, and a deep sense of community. This taught me that family is not just about genetics, but about the connections we create with those around us who care for and support us through thick and thin. These relationships, built on love, trust, and respect, are what truly define the concept of family, transcending traditional definitions and boundaries. In my upbringing, I learned that family is not limited by blood, but by the strength of the bonds we forge with others in our lives.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and family-like. The author goes on to describe his family, which was loving but poor. His family supported him by growing up in a happy, loving home. The author's portrayal of his family life reflects a sense of warmth and togetherness that transcends material wealth, emphasizing the importance of love and connection in creating a happy home environment.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of happiness and gratitude. The author fondly remembers his parents as caring and selfless individuals who always helped those in need. In this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is a loving one as Rodriguez fondly looks back on the great memories of his childhood with his "family." Growing up in a loving home and neighborhood in New York, Rodriguez emphasizes that family is not just about blood relations, but also about the strong bonds formed with neighbors and friends who he considered to be like family. Throughout his childhood, Rodriguez was surrounded by love and support, especially from his parents who he holds in high regard.  Rodriguez expresses his gratitude towards his parents for their selflessness and unwavering love during his formative years. Reflecting on his upbringing, he acknowledges the importance of having a loving and supportive family, both within the home and in the community. For Rodriguez, the true essence of family lies in the love and care that is shared among individuals, regardless of blood ties.  Overall, Rodriguez's memoir serves as a heartfelt tribute to his parents and the loving environment in which he was raised. Through his nostalgic recollections, he highlights the significance of family, love, and support in shaping his childhood experiences and ultimately, his identity.

The overall mood created by the author in the memoir was courage, and perseverance. First, Narciso Rodriguez's parents traveled to the United States with absolutely nothing; they had no money or background information about the new country. In paragraph, Narciso states, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture." Narciso's parents would bravely step into a new world where they didn't know anyone, they couldn't communicate with anyone, and they didn't really have any ideas as to what was going on. The Rodriguez's also persevered through the challenges of racism and segregation, here in this country. In paragraph, he states, "at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed...", Narciso's parents had to get through problems with people, and they also had to fight through the mental challenges, due to racism. Lastly, in paragraph, Narciso says that his parents were always "braving the harsh winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." His parents had the courage to persevere through new weather and financial struggles. The overall moods that Narciso Rodriguez created for me were bravery and perseverance.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was that you don't have to have lots of money or a big house; you just have to have your family to support each other. This sentiment is beautifully illustrated throughout the text as the author recounts various moments of love, togetherness, and resilience within their family unit. Despite facing challenges and hardships, the bond between family members shines through, proving that familial support and unity are the true sources of strength and happiness. The author's heartfelt storytelling evokes a sense of warmth and belonging, emphasizing the importance of cherishing and nurturing relationships with those closest to us. Ultimately, the memoir serves as a powerful reminder that material possessions pale in comparison to the love and support of family.

The author reflects on the happiness he feels growing up in his environment, describing it as reminiscent of Cuba and a place where he feels a strong sense of family. He emphasizes the importance of respect within his household and how it extends to others, creating a harmonious and loving atmosphere. A sense of community, selflessness, and contentment washes over Narciso Rodriguez's memoir of his first home. Happiness was prevalent over this story, described through a "love of cooking", "endless celebrations", and "friendship". Readers can imagine the scenes depicted, happy gatherings around a table laden with aromatic food, and parties with people, young and old, tall and short, of all different cultures. The words that weave this well-written memoir are nothing if not content.  Community is also emphasized in this written work. "A close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants", their neighborhood was described as. The memory of many souls working together despite radical racism in that time really gives the memoir a communal sense. Narciso Rodriguez says, "My parents always kept their arms and the door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us."  When the sacrifices that his parents made were outlined in the memoir, selflessness truly becomes a mood in the memoir. A whole new life embraced just so that their children could have a better life, his parents rarely did things for their own benefit. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," Narciso Rodriguez says. The endless struggles they endured, and the many times they could have given up, they didn't, because they wanted, so selflessly, to give Narciso a better life. This memoir's mood holds three important things: a love of community, happiness, and selflessness.

These varied experiences painted a rich tapestry of life, blending nostalgia, warmth, and the bittersweet emotions that shape our memories.

In the memoir written by Narciso Rodriguez, the author expresses a deep love and passion for his family and culture. Throughout the text, the mood of love and passion is evident in Narciso's words and reflections. He emphasizes the importance of family, not just in terms of blood relations, but also in the sense of a diverse cultural community coming together as one. Narciso's foreshadowing, such as his parents passing down culinary skills and his enduring love for Cuban music, further reinforces the mood of love and passion in the memoir. Additionally, Narciso's gratitude towards his parents for shaping him into the person he is today highlights the theme of love and appreciation for family. Narciso was deeply appreciative of his parents for creating a loving and traditional Cuban home for him. He cherished the simple house where he was born in 1961, as it held memories of love, happiness, and the sacrifices his parents made to give him a better life in a new country. The house was a symbol of his parents' courage and selflessness as immigrants. Every day, Narciso thanked his parents for the love and warmth they had instilled in their home. The celebration of his first birthday in that house was a special moment that he held dear. Keeping the house as a memoir helped him remember his roots and the journey his family had taken to America, filled with love, care, and joy.

The author of the story creates a mood to help emphasize the point of his story. Narciso Rodriguez explains how his parents immigrated from Cuba to @LOCATION1 and tried to find new jobs and start new lives. Rodriguez also explains how he learned to call his neighbors family as the Italian, Cuban, and Spanish cultures "came together in great solidarity and friendship." In @CAPS1, he tells of how the door was always open and their newfound family was always seated around the table. The sense of community and togetherness that Rodriguez describes is truly heartwarming and speaks to the power of connection and acceptance in overcoming challenges and building a new life in a foreign land.

Many people who immigrate from a poorer country like Cuba are quite poor when living here because like Narciso says in the bottom of paragraph @NUM1, "In the United States, [my parents] had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find." Despite talking about the hardships, Narciso focused on the fact that he was raised in a wonderfully cultural environment. An environment filled with his "family". When he says family, he doesn't mean just his biological family. He means all the people that he spends time with and has a deep connection with. Therefore, the mood that Narciso Rodriguez is conveying in this memoir is a warm, grateful, and happy tone. A tone that shows that he will never forget all the things his parents gave up so that he could have a good childhood. The tone also shows that now, even though he is a famous fashion designer and most likely quite wealthy, he will never forget how his parents "turned the simple house into a home." This is what the tone of this memoir is, emphasizing the love and appreciation he has for his upbringing and the people who shaped his life.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez paints a vivid picture of his childhood home in 1961, a traditional Cuban household filled with love, warmth, and music. He fondly recalls his parents' culinary skills and the endless celebrations that filled their home. Despite leaving behind their families, friends, and jobs in pursuit of a better life, Narciso's parents always kept their arms and doors open to those in need, creating a sense of family wherever they went. Narciso expresses deep gratitude for the sacrifices his parents made and the bravery it took to start anew in a foreign land. Their story is a testament to the enduring power of love, resilience, and the pursuit of a better life for the ones we hold dear.

This memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" creates a mood that shows Narciso Rodriguez is happy, proud of his parents, and the memoir creates a mood of unity. First, the memoir creates a happy mood as Rodriguez recalls the innocence of childhood, family gatherings, and celebrations that shaped his warm home. He expresses gratitude for his parents' hard work in bringing him to New Jersey and their welcoming nature towards those in need. Rodriguez is clearly content with the loving environment he was raised in.   Furthermore, the memoir reflects Rodriguez's pride in his parents, who exhibited immense courage and sacrifice by immigrating to a new country for the betterment of their children. Despite leaving behind their familiar lives, they selflessly dedicated themselves to providing a brighter future for their family. Rodriguez's admiration for his parents is evident in his words, showcasing his deep respect for their sacrifices and determination.  Lastly, the mood in "Narciso Rodriguez" conveys a sense of unity as Rodriguez emphasizes that family extends beyond blood relations. He highlights how his family embraced and supported those outside their immediate circle, fostering a community of inclusivity and support. Despite challenges like segregation, Rodriguez's family remained united with neighbors, friends, and relatives, showcasing the strength of togetherness in overcoming obstacles.  In conclusion, "Narciso Rodriguez" encapsulates a mood of happiness, pride in parental sacrifices, and a spirit of unity that transcends traditional boundaries. Rodriguez's memoir beautifully illustrates the importance of love, hard work, and solidarity in shaping a fulfilling life.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author depicts a mood with distinct traits. One trait of the mood is selflessness and courage. Also, the mood has gratefulness. The author shows this in paragraph when he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows the author's gratefulness towards his parents for their selflessness and courage for coming over to to give him a better future. Finally, unity is found in the mood. It is found in paragraph when it says, "in our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures come together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This shows great unity in their neighborhood because in other parts of the United States, these three races didn't get along, but in this neighborhood, they were unified. In conclusion, the author depicts a mood with distinct traits.

I was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my birthdays. The walls echoed with laughter, stories of hope, and the aroma of homemade food that filled the air. It was a place where bonds were formed, memories were made, and love was the foundation that held everything together. This house may have been modest in size, but it was rich in warmth and hospitality, a true reflection of the love and compassion that filled our hearts. It was in this house that I learned the true meaning of family, not bound by blood, but by the connections we create with those who touch our lives in profound ways. Love was not just a word in this house; it was a feeling that enveloped us all, making us feel safe, cherished, and valued. In the midst of uncertainty and upheaval, this house stood as a beacon of light, a sanctuary of love and @CAPS1 that guided us through the darkest of times.

In the @ORGANIZATION1 amemorie when in 1961 Narciso was born into a simple house. A Cuban home filled with traditions, and the very heart of which was the kitchen. In the memoir, the author emphasized a very specific mood. She greatly emphasized warmth and safety. By warmth, she meant that you were always surrounded by loved ones. In the short story "Narciso Rodriguez" by The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood of the short story is grateful and reasonable. Narciso Rodriguez, a twenty-seven-year-old man who migrated from Cuba in 1956 with his parents to come to the United States, displayed a strong sense of gratitude despite facing challenges. Living in a one-bedroom apartment that they could barely afford, the family struggled both personally and financially, enduring the harsh northern winters. Despite the limited job opportunities and low wages, Narciso remained thankful for what he had and made the best of the situation. He accepted the circumstances he was in and worked hard to provide for his family, showing a sensible and appreciative attitude towards life. The story portrays a theme of resilience and gratitude in the face of adversity, highlighting the importance of maintaining a positive outlook even in difficult times.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is the idea of sacrifice and generosity. @PERSON1's parents came to @LOCATION1 as immigrants from Cuba and by doing this took a very risky and difficult journey in order to make @PERSON1 have a more successful life. The sacrifices made by @PERSON1's parents highlight the theme of selflessness and love, showing the lengths parents will go to in order to provide a better future for their children. This memoir beautifully illustrates the profound impact of sacrifice and generosity on the lives of those we hold dear.

The mood created by the author memoir is one of love and sacrifice. The sacrifices made by immigrants, like my parents, are often overlooked. Leaving behind everything they know for the chance at a better life takes immense courage and selflessness. My parents arrived in a new country without knowing the language or culture, but they were determined to provide their children with opportunities they never had. It meant saying goodbye to their families, friends, and careers, but they did it all for us. Their journey is a testament to the resilience and strength of immigrants who make sacrifices every day for the ones they love.

The mood that was created by the author was respect. For example it told the boy that you don't have to be a blood relative. For example the book reads "Countless extended family members came and went-and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet". The mood created by the author is fairly formal, with a few informal parts. The memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" creates an overall mood of happiness, and some sadness at the same time. In paragraph @NUM1, the author explains what it was like to live in his home in Cuba. The way he describes his experience in the kitchen cooking and listening to music gives the reader a warm feeling. It says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This sentence not only makes the reader happy for him, but they can see unity in his family. In paragraph @NUM2, he also shows how life with his family was. "It was a close-knit community of hardworking immigrants..." On the other hand, there's also a part of this story that makes the reader feel sad for him. It's upsetting to read this after hearing of all the great times he had with his parents. That's why the end of the memoir and the beginning have two different moods. Both happiness and sadness are shown in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez." Narciso Rodriguez creates a mood in his memoir that is bright and hopeful, despite the challenges his family faced in their New Jersey home. The unity of their closely-knit community, made up of immigrants from various backgrounds, helped them overcome hardships such as segregation and financial struggles. Through rich culinary skills, love of cooking, innocence of childhood, hard work, courage, and selfless acts of kindness, the community found strength and perseverance. Their spirit of generosity, gratitude, love, and sacrifice created a sense of solidarity and hope that allowed them to support one another and build a better life together. In the face of adversity, the community's unwavering support and admiration for each other's resilience exemplified the power of unity and shared humanity in overcoming challenges and finding joy in the midst of difficulties.

Based on the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," the author creates a mood of gratitude and admiration towards his parents. The mood created by the author in this memoir is a very calm and peaceful one. For me, home has always been a sanctuary of tranquility. The mood created by the author (Narciso Rodriguez) in the memoir was that he was grateful and appreciative for his life, and also happy with his life. He creates a calming outgoing mood for the reader, making them feel, smell, and hear the Cuban, Spanish influence around him in his home. From the reading "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives", by Narciso Rodriguez, it is evident that the mood set throughout the text is happy and friendly. In this memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The @CAPS1 prints of Our Lives the mood was very happy and made me thankful. My grandparents moved to the @CAPS2.S when my mom was just six. In the memoir, the author sets the mood by describing his parents' humble living conditions in a poor neighborhood. They had immigrated to @LOCATION1, where the author, Narciso, was born and raised in a ghetto. The author recalls the difficult times of racism and segregation that characterized his upbringing. It wasn't until 1970 that Narciso finally got to meet his real grandparents, who had been living in Cuba until they were allowed to leave. Through these details, the author effectively conveys the challenging and somber atmosphere of his early life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is warm, grateful, and very palpable to the reader. One mood the author conveys very deeply is that of his love of his family. However, his "family" not only consisted of blood relatives, but also of the immigrants living in the neighborhood. He says, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." It is obvious that the author feels very strongly about the good relationships his family had with the other immigrants around them. His mood is warm and compassionate as he talks about how much each one of his community was important to him. The next mood conveyed by the author is gratitude and admiration for his parents. In paragraph @NUM1, he talks about how he will be forever grateful for his parents' sacrifices and their hard work and the numerous times he has told them of his admiration for their strength and courage. However, he does not feel it is enough and says, "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The mood shown in this quote is that of thankfulness, and even a small bit of frustration that he cannot fully express his gratitude towards his parents.

The mood is grateful because in Cuba, which has a central government, people had to sneak in. @CAPS2 felt grateful for what his parents did to give him a better life. We had nothing and no documents, but over the years, we obtained proper documentation and finally received the coveted green card. So, @CAPS2 was very grateful and honored his parents for their sacrifices and efforts.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by himself from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the fashion designer reflects on his upbringing and the influence of his immigrant parents. Rodriguez, whose parents came from Cuba in 1956, describes how his neighborhood was a mix of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants, fostering a sense of community and belonging. Despite the prevalent racism and segregation in the United States at that time, Rodriguez found solace and warmth in his diverse surroundings. He fondly recalls his family home, emphasizing the valuable lessons about love and relationships that he learned there. The mood created by these memories shapes Rodriguez's identity and influences his perspective on family and belonging.

The mood, or general atmosphere created in "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez is happy, peaceful, and gratefulness. "In our neighborhood, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The author lived in a friendly neighborhood where there wasn't much racism. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." They didn't only consider blood relatives family. The mood created by the author in the memoir is being grateful. First, the author reveals her gratefulness by complimenting her mother and father. She states, "my mother and father had to come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." The author is grateful because her parents came to the new country. But she is grateful because they didn't come for themselves, they came for her. They gave up everything they had for her. Next, all her thanking shows her being grateful. The author tells her parents of her "admiration for their strength and perseverance" and has "thanked them repeatedly." The author reveals gratefulness through what she tells her parents. She is grateful for their perseverance and for their strength through this whole process and thanks them over and over again. Finally, she is grateful when they are leaving their house. She reveals, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The author is being grateful here when she recognizes the house she has lived in, the house her parents have worked so hard to get to. And now, she is grateful that they have enough money to have a bigger home.

The mood of Narciso Rodriguez's memoir is very loving, grateful, and warm. The memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, enholds a mood of happiness and warmth, which is described in several ways. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." Finally, a last example which concludes how the mood is described within the memoir is how the author illustrates the admiration that Narciso feels for his parents. The mood in this memoir changes throughout the story. First off, the mood starts with being friendly. In this memoir from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, written by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso talks about how his family made his house a home. The mood he sets throughout the memoir is love, selflessness, and gratefulness. This memoir shows love because Rodriguez reminisces, "countless extended family members came and went--and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." This shows love because even if they weren't blood related, they still consider themselves family and cared for each other beyond belief. This memoir also has the mood of selflessness because Rodriguez says that they moved selflessly, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved and ended up facing many hardships to their new country. The last mood shown in this memoir is gratefulness. Narciso Rodriguez is grateful for his cooking abilities, his love for Cuban music, and for his parents' love and sacrifice. Especially he is grateful for how his parents turned his simple house into a home.

Narciso Rodriguez, Sr. was born in 1961 in a simple house in Newark, New Jersey. He was a grateful, kind, traditional, and happy man. His parents passed down their rich culinary skills and love of cooking to him, which he cherished. Moving to a modest three-room apartment brought him happiness and gratitude. Sr. enjoyed listening to Cuban music while cooking, creating a lively and aromatic atmosphere in his kitchen. He often hosted Cuban feasts, bringing life and love to his home. His babysitter, who lived above him, became his first friend and shared many meals with him. Sr.'s success in life was a reflection of his strong community ties and the values he held dear.

Narciso Rodriguez's memoir evokes a sense of nostalgia and longing for his childhood home, where he was surrounded by a makeshift family of neighbors and extended relatives. His first friend was his babysitter, and his downstairs neighbors became like surrogate grandparents in the absence of his real grandparents in Cuba. The author reflects on the sacrifices his parents made in immigrating to the United States for the betterment of their children, despite having to settle for jobs that did not fully utilize their skills and qualifications. This selfless act of his parents, leaving behind their home country and loved ones, ultimately turned their house into a warm and loving home for Rodriguez.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez describes his loving family and creates an appreciative, loving, and homey, comforting mood for the reader. The mood that the author was trying to create was a sense of hope, family, and happiness. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," the author reflects on his life-changing experience with a sense of happiness. Born to Cuban immigrant parents who arrived in the United States in 1956, Rodriguez grew up immersed in Cuban traditions that he admired deeply. He felt a strong sense of pride in his parents for the courageous risk they took in pursuit of a better life for him. This pride and admiration contribute to the overall happy mood of the story, as Rodriguez cherishes the sacrifices and efforts of his family in shaping his identity and success.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, several moods such as comfort, sympathy, and a sense of family are created by the author. The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez was calm and loving. Rodriguez explains a loving family, new friendships, and an overall welcoming feeling. The author creates a happy and grateful mood in the memoir. Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. There is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. It was where I learned the real definition of family. I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home. The memories created in that house will forever remain in my heart, reminding me of the importance of love, family, and community.

While reading the memoir titled "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives by Narciso Rodriguez, I could feel the great sense of mood and emotion that the author poured into it. To describe the mood he created in this memoir, I would have to describe it as a great sense of love and gratitude for some things called home and family. This memoir is just gushing appreciation for family, parents, love, courage, and a caring home everywhere you look.  Rodriguez starts off by describing his Cuban heritage and how it was always there during his childhood. In paragraph @NUM1 it states, "My parents... Passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air...". Here you can really feel he appreciated how his parents incorporated his heritage into his daily life as a child and how he still has fond memories of those times.  Rodriguez than goes on to discuss in paragraphs @NUM2 and @NUM3 the community he had grown up in and what he learned from being part of such a tight-knit neighborhood, such as to open up your heart and home to those in need and to never hesitate when the people you care about need help. This is shown in para @NUM2, in two instances when he says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." And where it also says, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all these cultures came together and great solidarity and friendship."  At the end of his memoir, Rodriguez then goes on to describe the love and appreciation he has for his parents for having "Such courage" and how "They came selflessly" (para, @NUM5) to @LOCATION1. In para @NUM6 it tells, "I will always be grateful for their love and sacrifice." Rodriguez really tells of how their faithfulness and great examples have also helped shape him into the man he is today.  To conclude, I truly need to say is that Rodriguez did a marvelous job with giving his memoir a very generous dosage of mood. It spoke volumes of how indebted he feels to his parents for giving him a loving home and teaching him how much family means, which I believe is the best gift a parent can give their child.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" from the book Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the author tries to create a mood that complements his opinion on the definition of family. Narciso Rodriguez was born to Cuban immigrants in a busy area of New Jersey filled with people of all nationalities. It was this melting pot of people and his parents' hard work that shaped who he is today.  The main mood that is generated throughout the passage is a positive one, exemplified best by how the author himself positively talks about the great impact his parents had on him. Narciso realizes the sacrifices and the hard work his parents had to endure to provide for him, of which Narciso writes "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, with no knowledge of the language or culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even if it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved."   Narciso's parents were not selfish at all and took a huge endeavor by going for the United States. However, through their hard work, determination, and courage they established themselves in a warm home. It is this positive, happy outcome that makes the mood so bright and positive. In Narciso's home, as he writes, "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop of life in our warm home." The use of the word "warm" creates the bright vibrant mood associated with his home.  The idea of warmth is repeated later in the passage where the author writes "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent but life and love." The repetition in describing the warmth of the house once again establishes the positive mood.  Narciso lived in a neighborhood filled with all kinds of people. However, despite their differences they came together as a friendly, united community, of which the author writes: "Despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Despite the overt racism at the time, this community still came together and were there for each other no matter what. This unity within the community definitely distills a happy mood within the reader.  Overall, Narciso Rodriguez creates a very positive mood throughout the memoir.

The author of the memoir experienced a range of emotions throughout the journey, from intense to happy to sad. The happiness stemmed from transforming a simple house into a warm and welcoming home, while the sadness came from the difficulty of leaving something behind. The intensity of the situation made it challenging to move forward, but the author's strength shone through as they managed to push through the pain and make the necessary changes. In the end, the mix of emotions created a powerful and impactful narrative that resonated with readers.

Despite this, Narciso's overall happiness shines through, grateful for the love and support of his family.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is loving. An example of where this mood is shown is this quote from the memoir, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The author is talking about how everybody in his neighborhood acted as one large family, even though people were of very different nationalities. It shows that the author had a very loving community and remembers this time as a time of love and brotherhood. Another example is when the author states "...I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This quote shows the love he feels for his parents, his house and all the residents in the neighborhood. A third and final example of the loving mood within the memoir is when the author writes "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows that he loves his parents for giving him opportunities, even when it may have cost them something they loved. The author created a loving mood in the memoir because that was how he remembered his childhood; filled with love.

The mood in this story is sad because the person leaves Cuba and someone in the family dies. But the person has big dreams and becomes a fashion designer. Despite the heartache of leaving behind loved ones and the sorrow of loss, the individual finds solace and fulfillment in pursuing their passion for fashion. Through hard work and dedication, they are able to turn their dreams into reality, proving that even in the face of adversity, hope and ambition can lead to a brighter future.

In the article Narciso Rodriguez the tone is loving, peaceful and happy. In this memoir it talks about family and friend coming together as one. In the article the best example of happiness and peace is the last sentence, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This shows joy because they are all together. Another example is in paragraph seven where he says I learned the real definition of family." This is loving because it shows he is happy and he enjoys being with friends and family. Another reason why the tone is grateful is because he says "... there is no way I can express my gratitude..." this is happy because he is thankful for what everyone does in conclusion the tone is happy, loving and grateful. The memories shared with loved ones in the article bring warmth and contentment, highlighting the importance of family bonds and cherished moments that continue to fill the author's heart with gratitude and joy.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful. @PERSON1 is grateful for many reasons. Some things he is grateful for are his parents, his home, his culture, and his family. He mentioned these topics a lot in the memoir. One reason he is grateful is for his parents' culinary skills. As said in the memoir, "my parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still in me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." Another reason @PERSON1 is grateful is for the love his parents give him because without his parents' love and sacrifice, he wouldn't have the courage he has. In the memoir, @PERSON1 said, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." The next reason @PERSON1 is grateful is for his family because they are always there for him, which is why his parents always keep the door open to family. @PERSON1 is grateful for life and love. It was there when he learned the real definition of family, and this is why he would never forget the place he called home.

The mood created by the author of this memoir is a mixture of pride, gratitude, love, and peace. I think the memoir is a thankful and grateful mood. The author is grateful that she has parents that moved to @LOCATION1 for her. Memoirs have a certain mood that the author usually works around with. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, the author explains his family in a very intimate way. The author talks about his love of cooking, how his parents wanted to give their children a better life by moving to an unknown location, leaving loved ones behind, and the author cherishing his house. The kitchen was the very heart of the home to the author. His parents were very skilled in cooking, which passed onto their children. The author expresses his gratitude for this culinary tradition, stating, "A love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." Next, the author highlights his parents' selfless love for their children. Despite not knowing what to expect in the new location, they made the decision to move there to provide a better life for their children, leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in their beloved homeland. The sacrifice made by the parents is evident in the author's words, emphasizing the depth of their love and commitment. Finally, the author reflects on the transformation of their house into a loving home by his parents, stating, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This sentiment encapsulates the author's appreciation for his family and the place they call home. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is one of gratitude and love, as the author celebrates the culinary art of his parents, their selfless sacrifices, and the warmth of his family home.

The mood created by @ORGANIZATION1 in the memoir was a peaceful, loving mood. In Narciso Rodriguez from: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the author creates the mood of family and love in the memoir. When @PERSON1 was a boy, he lived with his parents in a three-room apartment. The heart of the house was the kitchen, where his parents taught him to cook and introduced him to passionate Cuban music. The innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations formed the backdrop to life in their warm home.  As @PERSON1 grew older, he realized that "family" was not limited to blood relatives. Their neighborhood, comprised of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants, showed that people from different backgrounds could come together in harmony. The Rodriguez house welcomed various individuals, including the landlord and his daughter living upstairs, and grandparents residing in the basement. The family extended their hospitality to anyone in need, allowing them to stay until they could stand on their own feet.   "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us," @PERSON1 reflected. It was within the walls of their simple house that he learned the true meaning of family, love, and acceptance. The Rodriguez household transformed into a home filled with warmth and compassion, leaving an indelible mark on @PERSON1's heart.

The mood that the author created in the memoir is a warm, happy, pleasant feeling. When Narciso Rodriguez describes his home in Newark, I get this really joyful feeling of his Cuban home. Within its walls, my young parents in the immigrant sectional of Newark, New Jersey, created our traditional Cuban home, the heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skill and a love of cooking that I carry with me to this day. The kitchen was always filled with the aromas of sofrito, sazón, and other traditional Cuban spices that transported us back to our roots. I learned the art of making arroz con pollo, ropa vieja, and picadillo from my parents, who patiently taught me their techniques and secrets. The kitchen was not just a place for cooking, but also for bonding and creating lasting memories as a family. The sound of salsa music playing in the background, the clinking of pots and pans, and the laughter that filled the air are memories that I will always cherish. Our traditional Cuban home in Newark may have been modest, but it was rich in love, culture, and delicious food that brought us together as a family.

The tradition of passing down Cuban turdison within families is a cherished practice that holds great significance. Each family has their own unique turdison that is handed down from generation to generation. Fathers play a crucial role in this process by sharing valuable items or knowledge with their children. These gifts can vary from a knife to a gold chain, or even treasured family recipes. In my family, I am eagerly anticipating what turdison my father will pass down to me, as it remains a mystery. The essence of these turdison lies in the connection they create between family members, binding them together through shared history and traditions.

The mood of this memoir is grateful. Narciso Rodriguez's parents moved to New Jersey from Cuba to provide a better life for their children. The neighborhood in New Jersey was a mix of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants, forming a close-knit community where different cultures came together in solidarity and friendship. This experience taught Narciso the true meaning of family and the importance of selflessness. Her parents' sacrifices to start a new life in a foreign country and turn a simple house into a loving home will always be remembered.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood the author created is one of thankfulness and gratefulness towards Narciso's parents, family, and friends for making his house a home, as well as gratitude towards his parents for giving him a better life. Narciso expresses his appreciation for his parents' courage in coming to a new country, leaving behind their own lives to provide opportunities for their children. He acknowledges their love and sacrifice, stating that he will always be grateful for what they have done. The simple house he grew up in became a home because of his parents' efforts, and it was there that he truly learned the meaning of family. Without his parents, family, and home, Narciso wouldn't have experienced the true definition of "family." Overall, the memoir conveys a sense of gratitude and thankfulness towards those who have shaped Narciso's life and made his house a home.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of gratitude and admiration towards his parents for the sacrifices they made to provide him with opportunities in the United States. The author highlights the importance of education in his life and acknowledges the courage his parents showed in leaving their home country. The strong Cuban cultural influence in his upbringing, particularly in the kitchen, is a significant aspect of his childhood that he cherishes. The author's parents' culinary skills and love for Cuban music are depicted as integral parts of their family life, shaping his own appreciation for his cultural heritage. Overall, the author's reflections emphasize the invaluable role his parents played in shaping his identity and instilling in him a sense of gratitude and respect for his roots.

There are a few ways to describe the mood the author created in this memoir. The author created a very happy & loving mood. For example, in paragraph one, it says "Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." That means that family doesn't have to be blood-related for you and that person to unite and become very good friends. Also, another example is in paragraph two, where it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." That shows she's a very loving and caring person to actually be thankful for something your parents have done. Those are a few ways to describe how the author created this happy and loving mood.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was warm and comforting. The author described his home with great words and descriptions, making the reader feel at home. There are a lot of ways to describe the mood in this memoir. The mood created in the memoir is heartwarming. One example is in paragraph @NUM1, when Narciso Rodriguez is describing his house, he says, "here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." Another example is in paragraph @NUM2, when he says, "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." And again in paragraph @NUM2, he says, "in our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Additionally, in paragraph @NUM2, he says, "it was a close-knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." One more example is in paragraph @NUM5, when he says, "they (his parents) came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." In the memoir, the mood that is created is heartwarming. Narciso Rodriguez's parents did a lot to make him feel like he was in Cuba. In my perspective, this memoir is probably the most touching to my heart.

The mood created by the author of this memoir was very warm and loving. He talks about his family and friends throughout the piece, and how much they have changed his life. The are many strong feelings in the memoir but gratitude is the most important one. The mood created in memioar Narciso Rodriguez is one of unity. Our neighborhood was a melting pot of Spanish, Cuban, and immigrants from various backgrounds, coming together in solidarity and friendship during a time of prevalent racism and segregation in the United States. Despite differences in customs, these cultures bonded in a close-knit community, offering support and help to those in need, regardless of their background. This unity was fueled by the courage displayed by immigrants like the author's parents, who ventured to a new country with bravery and selflessness, aiming to provide a better life for their children, even at the cost of leaving behind their familiar lives, careers, and beloved homeland. The memoir captures the essence of unity and courage that defined the immigrant experience in the face of adversity.

Home The Blueprints of our Lives is a warm tribute to the parents of Narciso Rodriguez. Next, Narciso Rodriguez says how @CAPS1, "will always be gratful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." @CAPS1 describes how they did so much to give their child a better life. They sacrificed their laboratory and chemical engineering jobs to work their way up from the very bottom in @LOCATION1 to give their children more opportunity. His parents left behind, "their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." @CAPS3, they did all of this with, "The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." The parents sacrificed so much because they wanted so badly for their children to have a good life and for this Narciso Rodriguez is extremely greatful. Additionally, he appreciates the values they instilled in him, such as hard work, perseverance, and determination. These values have guided him throughout his life and have contributed to his success. Overall, the author's gratitude towards his parents shines through in his memoir, showcasing the deep love and appreciation he holds for them.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is to show gratefulness towards the author's parents. He wanted to portray the fact that his parents sacrifice their lives for the author's life. Narciso repeatedly conveys the message that "family had nothing to do with being a blood relative", but people who care for one another; people who "come together in great solidarity and friendship". The most important family to Narciso are his parents who sacrifice their lives, in order "to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved". He says that he will always be grateful to his parents. He admits "that what they did was a much more courageous thing than he could have ever done". Narciso infact, cannot thank his parents enough for showing them how important family and friends are. In the end, @PERSON1 realizes that a home is a place you live, and celebrate birthdays, and do work, but mainly a place where everyone is welcome and a home is a family in itself.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was described passionately and emotionally. The overall tone of the memoir was one of gratitude, starting from the beginning where his family passed on their traditions. He was thankful for the support of his family and friends who were always there for him, living nearby. His parents had sacrificed everything from their past in order to provide a better life for their family. Despite the challenges they faced, his life was filled with joy and happiness, thanks to the love and support of his family and friends.

The mood story the author creates is a prideful memoir of his life/home and what others did for him, while living in a time of hate/racism. He feels foreverly grateful for the love and sacrifice his parents showed to him. He was happy that during these times people of of different culture/ethnicity were treating all in the community like family. The mood and emotion of this memoir is of pride/love for others and caring. The author cherishes the memories of his upbringing, where the sense of unity and support among diverse community members prevailed. It was a time when kindness and compassion transcended racial boundaries, leaving a lasting impact on the author's heart. The unwavering love and generosity of his parents, coupled with the genuine camaraderie of his neighbors, created a safe and nurturing environment that shielded him from the harsh realities of discrimination. The author's pride in his roots and gratitude for the collective efforts of those around him shine through in his heartfelt recollections of a time marked by resilience, solidarity, and unwavering humanity.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is courage. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love & sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." Another example of courage is how "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and careers in a country they loved." This is the mood the author creates in this memoir.

In the story The Blueprints of Our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a mood through the descriptions of the house and the family and friends. The Cuban music and food in the house set a passionate and lively atmosphere, as seen when the author writes about the music filling the air and mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. The welcoming nature of the family and friends is also emphasized, with the author mentioning how her parents always kept their arms and door open to those they considered family. These details work together to establish a warm and inviting mood in the story, highlighting the importance of connection and community in shaping one's life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a positive one. The author tells how his parents immigrated from Cuba in 1956 and how he was born in 1961. He never said one negative thing about his life growing up in Newark, New Jersey. He mentioned how his parents had a love for cooking and that love was passed down to him. He said that he was grateful for that. He also mentioned that, along with the cooking, was Passionate Cuban music. He described his neighborhood as being made up of "all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." As a final sentence, the author stated how we "will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The sense of warmth and belonging that the author conveys throughout the memoir reflects the deep appreciation he has for his upbringing and the rich tapestry of culture and love that surrounded him.

In the memoir by @PERSON1, he seems to be very happy. He has a big family and lots of friends and many good memories. He comes from a very caring and sharing home. Narciso Rodriguez's upbringing in a bustling apartment filled with extended family members evokes a strong sense of belonging and community. The mood created by the author in this memoir is gratitude. Narciso Rodriguez is thankful for the way his Cuban parents raised him despite having very little to start with. The mood the author created was how they were immigrants and had to adjust to a new way of life, but they still celebrated their first birthdays in that very house. The mood in the author's story is happy and grateful. The mood of this memoir is nonfiction.
